{{Infobox person | name = Eunice Kennedy Shriver
[[Order of St. Gregory the Great|DSG]] | image = Eunice-Kennedy.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Eunice Mary Kennedy | birth_date = {{birth date|1921|7|10}} | birth_place = {{nowrap|[[Brookline, Massachusetts]], U.S.}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|8|11|1921|7|10}} | death_place = {{nowrap|[[Hyannis, Massachusetts]], U.S.}} |resting_place = St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church parish cemetery, [[Centerville, Massachusetts]] |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = American |education = [[Manhattanville College]] | alma_mater = [[Stanford University]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Sargent Shriver]]|1953}} | parents = [[Joseph P. Kennedy, Sr.]]
[[Rose Kennedy|Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy]] | children = {{plainlist| * [[Bobby Shriver]] * [[Maria Shriver]] * [[Timothy Shriver]] * [[Mark Shriver]] * [[Anthony Shriver]] }} | signature = Eunice Kennedy Shriver (signature).jpg | family = [[Kennedy family|Kennedy]] | website = {{URL|http://www.eunicekennedyshriver.org}} }} '''Eunice Mary Kennedy Shriver''', [[Order of St. Gregory the Great|DSG]] (July 10, 1921 – August 11, 2009){{cite news |last=Grinberg |first=Emanuella |date=n.d. |title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver dies |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/11/eunice.kennedy.shriver/ |accessdate=August 11, 2009}} was a member of the [[Kennedy family]]. She was a sister of President [[John F. Kennedy]] and senators [[Robert F. Kennedy]] and [[Ted Kennedy]]. Her husband, [[Sargent Shriver]], was the [[United States Ambassador to France]] during the [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] presidency. In 1962, Shriver founded Camp Shriver, which started on her Maryland farm known as Timberlawn, and evolved into [[Special Olympics]] in 1968.{{cite web |title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver |website=Special Olympics |url=http://www.specialolympics.org/eunice_kennedy_shriver_biography.aspx |access-date=2017-09-04}} ==Early life== Eunice Mary Kennedy was born in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]]. She was the fifth of nine children of [[Joseph P. Kennedy, Sr.]], and [[Rose Kennedy|Rose Fitzgerald]]. Shriver was educated at the Convent of The Sacred Heart, Roehampton, London and at [[Manhattanville College]] in Upper Manhattan (the school later moved farther north to [[Purchase, New York|Purchase]], [[New York (state)|New York]]). After graduating from [[Stanford University]] with a [[bachelor of science]] degree in [[sociology]] in 1943,Smith, J.Y. (August 11, 2009). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/08/11/AR2009081100689.html?hpid=artslot "Eunice Kennedy Shriver, Founder of Special Olympics, Dies at 88"] ''[[The Washington Post]]''. Retrieved August 11, 2009. she worked for the Special War Problems Division of the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]]. She eventually moved to the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Justice Department]] as executive secretary for a project dealing with [[juvenile delinquency]]. She served as a [[social work]]er at the [[Alderson Federal Prison Camp|Federal Industrial Institution for Women]] for one year before moving to [[Chicago]] in 1951 to work with the [[House of the Good Shepherd]] [[women's shelter]] and the Chicago Juvenile Court.Baranauckas, Carla (August 12, 2009). [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/12/us/12shriver.html?ref=obituaries "Eunice Shriver, Founder of Special Olympics, Dies"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. (website registration required) In 1969, Shriver moved to France and pursued her interest in intellectual disability there. She started organizing small activities with Paris organizations, mostly reaching out to families of kids who had special needs to provide activities for them, laying the foundation for a robust international expansion of the Special Olympics in the late '70s and '80s.{{cite web |last=Cooper |first=Chet |title=Timothy Shriver — Special Olympics |publisher=ABILITY Magazine |url=http://abilitymagazine.com/Special-Olympics-Shriver.html |accessdate=18 February 2014}} ==Political career== Shriver actively campaigned for her elder brother, John, during his successful [[United States presidential election, 1960|1960 U.S. presidential election]]. In 1968, she helped [[Anne McGlone Burke]] nationalize the Special Olympics movement and is the only woman to have her portrait appear, during her lifetime, on a [[Coins of the United States dollar|U.S. coin]] – the 1995 [[Modern United States commemorative coins#1995|commemorative]] Special Olympics [[Dollar coin (United States)|silver dollar]]. Although Shriver was a Democrat, she was a vocal supporter of the [[pro-life movement]]. In 1990, Shriver wrote a letter to ''[[The New York Times]]'' denouncing the misuse of a quotation by President Kennedy used out of context by a [[pro-choice]] group.Biofiles: Eunice Kennedy Shriver [http://www.historyguy.com/biofiles/shriver_eunice_kennedy.htm]. Retrieved August 11, 2009. During [[Bill Clinton]]'s [[Bill Clinton presidential campaign, 1992|1992 Democratic U.S. presidential campaign]], she was one of several prominent Democrats – including [[List of Governors of Pennsylvania|Governor]] [[Robert P. Casey]] of [[Pennsylvania]], and [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|Bishop]] [[Austin Vaughan]] of [[New York (state)|New York]] – who signed a letter to ''The New York Times'' protesting the Democratic Party's pro-choice plank in its [[Party platform|platform]]. Shriver was a supporter of several pro-life organizations: [[Feminists for Life|Feminists for Life of America]],Shriver, Eunice Kennedy, [http://www.feministsforlife.org/taf/1998/winter/Winter98-99.pdf "Remarkable Pro-Life Women"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080529185826/http://www.feministsforlife.org/taf/1998/winter/Winter98-99.pdf |date=2008-05-29 }} ([[PDF]] format) ''[[The American Feminist]], The Quarterly Magazine of Feminists for Life of America'', Vol. 5, No. 4, Winter 1998–1999, p. 18. Accessed May 28, 2008. the [[Susan B. Anthony List]],[http://www.nndb.com/org/308/000164813 Susan B. Anthony List], [[Notable Names Database]]. Accessed May 28, 2008. and [[Democrats for Life of America]]. A lifelong [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]], Shriver supported her [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[son-in-law]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]'s successful [[California gubernatorial recall election, 2003|2003 Governor of California election]]. On January 28, 2008, Shriver was present at [[American University]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], when her brother, U.S. Senator [[Ted Kennedy|Edward M. Kennedy]], announced his endorsement of [[Barack Obama]]'s [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|2008 Democratic U.S. presidential campaign]].Alexander, Amy, [http://www.thenation.com/doc/20080211/alexander2 "A Torch Passed"], ''[[The Nation]]'', January 28, 2008. Retrieved August 11, 2009. {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} ==Charity work and awards== {{See also|List of Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients}} [[File:Eunice Kennedy Shriver in 1980.jpg|thumb|300px|Eunice Kennedy Shriver in 1980]] [[File:US-NIH-NICHD-2008Logo.svg|thumb|In 2008, the [[National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] was renamed in honor of Eunice Kennedy Shriver.]] [[File:Kennedy Shriver.jpg|thumb|Eunice Kennedy Shriver speaks at March 3, 2008 ceremony in her honor]] A longtime advocate for children's health and disability issues, Shriver was a key founder of the [[National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] (NICHD), a part of the [[National Institutes of Health]] in 1962. She has also helped to establish numerous other university programs, government initiatives, health-care facilities, and support service networks throughout the country. In 1961, she championed the creation of the President's Panel on Mental Retardation which was significant in the movement from institutionalization to [[community integration]] in the US and throughout the world, a major public policy challenge.Braddock, D. (2010, February). Honoring Eunice Kennedy Shriver's legacy in intellectual disability. ''Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities'', 48(1): 63–72. In 1982, Shriver founded the Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Center for Community of Caring at [[University of Utah|University of Utah, Salt Lake City]]. The Community is a ''"[[K–12 (education)|grades K-12]], whole school, comprehensive character education program with a focus on disabilities... adopted by almost 1,200 schools nationwide and in [[Canada]]."''[http://www.communityofcaring.org/about/index.html "About Community of Caring"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331112104/http://www.communityofcaring.org/about/index.html |date=2009-03-31 }}. Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Center for Community of Caring. Undated. Retrieved August 14, 2009. She was awarded the nation's highest civilian award, the (U.S.) [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]], in 1984 by U.S. President [[Ronald Reagan]], because of her work on behalf of those with [[intellectual disability]].[http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1984/32684a.htm "Remarks at the Presentation Ceremony for the Presidential Medal of Freedom"], Archives – Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, administered by the [[National Archives and Records Administration]]. March 26, 1984. Accessed May 28, 2008. In 1990 Shriver was awarded the Eagle Award from the [[United States Sports Academy]]. The Eagle Award is the Academy's highest international honor and was awarded to Shriver for her significant contributions to international sport.{{cite web |date=2008-01-21 |title=News 21/01/08 – FISU President Receives USSA Award |publisher=Fisu.net |url=http://www.fisu.net/en/News-210108-FISU-President-Receives-USSA-Award-2133.html |accessdate=2011-05-26}} In 1992, Shriver received the Award for Greatest Public Service Benefiting the Disadvantaged, an award given out annually by [[Jefferson Awards for Public Service|Jefferson Awards]].{{cite web |title=National - Jefferson Awards Foundation |publisher= |url=http://www.jeffersonawards.org/pastwinners/national}} For her work in nationalizing the Special Olympics, Shriver received the [[Civitan International]] World Citizenship Award.{{cite book |last=Armbrester |first=Margaret E. |year=1992 |title=The Civitan Story |publisher=Ebsco Media |location=Birmingham, AL |page=95}} Her advocacy on this issue has also earned her other awards and recognitions, including honorary degrees from numerous universities.[http://www.shrivercenter.org/about_ekshriver.html "Eunice Kennedy Shriver – Doctor of Public Service"] The Shriver Center, The University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Accessed May 28, 2008.{{cite web |title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver |work=[[Special Olympics]] |publisher=[[Internet Archive|archive.org]] |url=http://www.specialolympics.org/Special+Olympics+Public+Website/English/About_Us/Leaders/Mrs.+Shriver+Bio.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080128184416/http://www.specialolympics.org/Special%2BOlympics%2BPublic%2BWebsite/English/About_Us/Leaders/Mrs.%2BShriver%2BBio.htm |accessdate=August 12, 2009 |archivedate=2008-01-28 |deadurl=yes}} She is the second American and only woman to appear on a US coin while still living. Her portrait is on the obverse of the 1995 commemorative silver dollar honoring the Special Olympics. On the reverse is the quotation, "As we hope for the best in them, hope is reborn in us." In 1998, Shriver was inducted into the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]].[https://www.womenofthehall.org/inductee/eunice-kennedy-shriver/ National Women's Hall of Fame, Eunice Kennedy Shriver] Shriver received the 2002 [[Theodore Roosevelt Award (NCAA)|Theodore Roosevelt Award]] (the Teddy),Staff writer (August 11, 2009). [https://www.ncaa.org/wps/ncaa?key=/ncaa/ncaa/ncaa+news/ncaa+news+online/2009/association-wide/2002+teddy+winner+shriver+dies+at+88_08_11_09_ncaa_news "2002 Teddy winner Shriver dies at 88"]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''NCAA News'' (at the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]]). Retrieved August 15, 2009. an annual award given by the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] to a graduate from an NCAA member institution who earned a [[varsity letter]] in college for participation in [[college athletics|intercollegiate athletics]], and who ultimately became a distinguished citizen of national reputation based on outstanding life accomplishment. In addition to the Teddy recognition, she was selected in 2006 as part of the NCAA Centennial celebration as one of the 100 most-influential individuals in its first century; she was listed ninth. In 2006, she received a [[Papal Orders of Chivalry|papal knighthood]] from [[Pope Benedict XVI]], being made a Dame of the [[Order of St. Gregory the Great]] (DSG). Her mother had been created a [[papal count]]ess in 1950 by [[Pope Pius XII]].{{cite web|url=http://www.jfklibrary.org/JFK/The-Kennedy-Family/Rose-Fitzgerald-Kennedy.aspx|title=Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy - John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum|website=www.jfklibrary.org}} In 2008, the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] changed the NICHD's name to the ''Eunice Kennedy Shriver'' National Institute of Child Health and Human Development. In December 2008, ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' named Shriver the first recipient of [[Sportsman of the Year]] Legacy Award.{{cite web |title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver's legacy lives on with Special Olympics |publisher= |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/jack_mccallum/08/11/shriver/index.html}} On May 9, 2009, the [[Smithsonian Institution]]'s [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)|National Portrait Gallery]] (NPG) in Washington, D.C., unveiled an historic portrait of her, the first portrait the NPG has ever commissioned of an individual who had not served as a U.S. President or [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]]. The portrait depicts her with four Special Olympics athletes (including [[Loretta Claiborne]]) and one [[Best Buddies International|Best Buddies]] participant. It was painted by [[David Lenz]], the winner of the [[Outwin Boochever Portrait Competition]] in 2006. As part of the Portrait Competition prize, the NPG commissioned a work from the winning artist to depict a living subject for the collection. Lenz, whose son, Sam, has [[Down syndrome]] and is an enthusiastic Special Olympics athlete, was inspired by Shriver's dedication to working with people with intellectual disabilities. Shriver became involved with [[Dorothy Hamill]]'s special skating program in the Special Olympics after Hamill's [[Olympic Games]] [[ice skating|ice-skating]] win. In September 2010, the [[State University of New York at Brockport]], home of the 1979 Special Olympics, renamed its football stadium after Shriver.[http://www.democratandchronicle.com/article/20100925/SPORTS09/9250344/1007/SPORTS ]{{dead link|date=May 2011}} In July 2017, Shriver posthumously received the Arthur Ashe Courage Award at the 2017 ESPY Awards. ==Personal life== On May 23, 1953, Shriver married [[Sargent Shriver]] in a [[Roman Catholic]] ceremony at [[St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York|Saint Patrick's Cathedral]] in [[New York City]].Archives. [http://www.jfklibrary.org/Historical+Resources/Archives/Archives+and+Manuscripts/Shriver.Sargent/fa_shriver_long.htm R(obert) "Sargent Shriver: An Inventory of His Personal Papers, 1948–1976, Papers (#214) – J"] [[John F. Kennedy Library|John F. Kennedy Presidential Library & Museum]], John F. Kennedy Library National Archives and Records Administration Her husband served as the [[United States Ambassador to France|U.S. Ambassador to France]] from 1968 to 1970 and was the 1972 Democratic U.S. Vice Presidential candidate (with [[George McGovern]] as the candidate for [[President of the United States|U.S. President]]). They had five children: * [[Bobby Shriver|Robert Sargent Shriver III]] (born April 28, 1954) * [[Maria Shriver|Maria Owings Shriver]] (born November 6, 1955) * [[Timothy Shriver|Timothy Perry Shriver]] (born August 29, 1959) * [[Mark Shriver|Mark Kennedy Shriver]] (born February 17, 1964) * [[Anthony Shriver|Anthony Paul Kennedy Shriver]] (born July 20, 1965) With her husband, Shriver had nineteen grandchildren, the second-most of any of her siblings (her brother [[Robert F. Kennedy|Robert]] had eleven children who have produced thirty-four grandchildren).{{cite web |title=Taylor Swift -- "You Belong with Me" (2009) |website=2or3lines.blogspot.de |url=http://2or3lines.blogspot.de/2013/08/taylor-swift-you-belong-with-me-2009.html}} Her daughter Maria Shriver is divorced from actor and former [[California Governor]] [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]. As executive vice president of the [[Joseph P. Kennedy, Jr. Foundation]] in the 1950s, Shriver shifted the organization's focus from Catholic charities to research on the causes of intellectual disabilities and humane ways to treat them.{{cite news |last=Smith |first=J.Y. |date=August 12, 2009 |title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver, Special Olympics Founder, Dies at 88 |publisher=washingtonpost.com |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/08/11/AR2009081100689.html |accessdate=2010-03-02}} This interest eventually culminated in, among other things, the Special Olympics movement. Upon the death of her sister [[Rosemary Kennedy]] on January 7, 2005, Shriver became the eldest of the four then-surviving children of Joseph and Rose Kennedy. Her sister [[Patricia Kennedy Lawford|Patricia Kennedy]] died on September 17, 2006, and her brother [[Ted Kennedy|Edward M. Kennedy]] died on August 25, 2009, leaving former [[United States Ambassador to Ireland|U.S. Ambassador to Ireland]] [[Jean Kennedy Smith]] as the only surviving sibling.Staff writer. [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/TedKennedy/story?id=6692022 "Ted Kennedy Dies of Brain Cancer at Age 77 — 'Liberal Lion' of the Senate Led Storied Political Family After Deaths of President John F. Kennedy, Sen. Robert F. Kennedy"]. ''[[ABC News]]''. Retrieved August 26, 2009. ==Later years and death== Shriver, who was believed to have suffered from [[Addison's disease]],{{cite book|title=An Unfinished Life: John F. Kennedy, 1917–1963 |first=Robert|last=Dallek |authorlink=Robert Dallek |year=2003|pages=105, 731|publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |location=[[London]]|isbn=978-0-14-101535-4}} suffered a stroke and broken hip in 2005. On November 18, 2007, she was admitted to [[Massachusetts General Hospital]] in [[Boston]], where she spent several weeks.{{cite news|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/11/25/AR2007112500627_pf.html |title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver Hospitalized|date= November 25, 2007|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[The Washington Post|washingtonpost.com]] |accessdate=2009-08-12}}Beggy, Carol and Mark Shanahan, [http://www.boston.com/ae/celebrity/articles/2008/01/14/shes_loyal_to_fathers_ideal/ "She's loyal to father's 'Ideal'"], ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', January 14, 2008. Retrieved August 11, 2009. On August 7, 2009, she was admitted to [[Cape Cod Hospital]] in [[Hyannis, Massachusetts|Hyannis]], with an undisclosed ailment.McGreevy, Patrick. [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2009/08/schwarzenegger-maria-shriver-at-eunice-shrivers-bedside.html "Schwarzenegger, Maria Shriver at Eunice Shriver's bedside"], [[Los Angeles Times]]. August 7, 2009. Retrieved August 7, 2009. On August 10, her relatives were called to the hospital.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/POLITICS/08/10/eunice.kennedy.shriver/index.html|title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver's relatives called to hospital|author=Staff writer |publisher=CNN.com|date=August 11, 2009|accessdate=August 11, 2009}} Early the next morning, Shriver died at the hospital; she was 88 years old.{{cite web|url=http://www.politico.com/news/stories/0809/26007.html|title=Eunice Kennedy Shriver dies |last=Allen|first=Mike |publisher=Politico.Com |date= August 11, 2009|accessdate=August 11, 2009}} Shriver's family issued a statement upon her death, reading in part: {{quote|Inspired by her love of God, her devotion to her family, and her relentless belief in the dignity and worth of every human life, she worked without ceasing—searching, pushing, demanding, hoping for change. She was a living prayer, a living advocate, a living center of power. She set out to change the world and to change us, and she did that and more. She founded the movement that became Special Olympics, the largest movement for acceptance and inclusion for people with intellectual disabilities in the history of the world. Her work transformed the lives of hundreds of millions of people across the globe, and they in turn are her living legacy.{{cite web |url=http://www.eunicekennedyshriver.org/articles/article/171|title=Statement from The Shriver Family |publisher=Eunice Kennedy Shriver's website|date= 2009-08-11|accessdate=2009-08-11}}}} [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] remarked after Shriver's death that she was "an extraordinary woman who, as much as anyone, taught our nation—and our world—that no physical or mental barrier can restrain the power of the human spirit."{{cite news |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/afterword/2010/08/one-year-ago-eunice-kennedy-shriver.html|title=One year ago: Eunice Kennedy Shriver|date=August 11, 2010 |first=Michael|last=Farr|publisher=''Los Angeles Times''}} ===Funeral and burial=== On August 14, 2009, an invitation-only [[Requiem Mass]] was celebrated for Shriver at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Hyannis. Following the Requiem Mass, she was buried at the St. Francis Xavier parish cemetery in nearby [[Centerville, Massachusetts|Centerville]].Staff writer (August 14, 2009). [http://www2.turnto10.com/jar/news/local/article/biden_among_invitees_to_eunice_kennedy_shriver_funeral_mass/21671/ "Special Olympians, Family Celebrate Eunice Kennedy Shriver"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817212151/http://www2.turnto10.com/jar/news/local/article/biden_among_invitees_to_eunice_kennedy_shriver_funeral_mass/21671/ |date=2009-08-17 }}. ''[[Associated Press|The Associated Press]]'' (at [[WJAR]] television's website turnto10.com). Retrieved August 16, 2000. Pope [[Benedict XVI]] sent a letter of condolence to her family.{{cite web|url=http://www.zenit.org/article-26630?l=english|title=Pope's Letter to Kennedy-Shriver Family|accessdate=2009-08-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608004113/http://www.zenit.org/article-26630?l=english |archivedate=2011-06-08|df=}} Because her brother [[Ted Kennedy|Ted]] had [[terminal illness|terminal]] [[brain cancer]], he was unable to attend the funeral,McMullen, Troy (August 26, 2009). [http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/TedKennedy/story?id=8421544 "The Last Kennedy — Death of Ted Kennedy Leaves One Surviving Child of Joseph and Rose Kennedy"]. ''[[ABC News]]''. Retrieved August 26, 2009. and their sister Jean Smith stayed with him. Ted died two weeks later, leaving Jean as the sole surviving child of Joseph and Rose Kennedy. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} * [[Kennedy family]] * [[Kennedy family#Family tree|Kennedy family tree]] * [[National Institute of Child Health and Human Development]] * [[Special Olympics]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book |author=Eileen McNamara |title=Eunice: The Kennedy Who Changed the World |isbn=978-1451642261 |publisher=Simon & Schuster |year=2018 }} ==External links== *[http://www.eunicekennedyshriver.org/ Eunice Kennedy Shriver Official website] * Shriver, Maria (August 14, 2009). Transcript. [http://www.boston.com/news/local/breaking_news/2009/08/maria_shivers_e.html "Maria Shriver's Eulogy of Her Mother"], ''[[The Boston Globe]]''. Accessed August 31, 2009. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090813080800/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Statement-from-the-President-on-the-passing-of-Eunice-Kennedy-Shriver/ "Statement from the President on the Passing Of Eunice Kennedy Shriver"], (August 11, 2009) on the [[White House]]'s website * Staff writer (undated). [http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/bostonglobe/obituary.aspx?n=eunice-kennedy-shriver&pid=131238476 "Eunice Kennedy Shriver"], obituary by ''[[Associated Press|The Associated Press]]'' (at ''[[The Boston Globe]]'') * Staff writer (August 11, 2009). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/politics-obituaries/6010353/Eunice-Kennedy-Shriver.html "Eunice Kennedy Shriver"], obituary at ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090817212151/http://www2.turnto10.com/jar/news/local/article/biden_among_invitees_to_eunice_kennedy_shriver_funeral_mass/21671/ "Special Olympians, Family Celebrate Eunice Kennedy Shriver"], article on funeral and burial by ''[[Associated Press|The Associated Press]]'' (at [[WJAR]] television's website turnto10.com) * {{IMDb name|0447885}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080828023528/http://www.communityofcaring.org/ communityofcaring.org], Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Center for Community of Caring's official website * Shapiro, Joseph, [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=9136962 Eunice Kennedy Shriver's Olympic Legacy], (April 5, 2007) ''[[Morning Edition]]'' on [[National Public Radio]]'s website (includes [[podcast]] as well as text) * [http://www.usmint.gov/kids/coinNews/coinOfTheMonth/2002/06.cfm Coin of the Month], [[United States Mint|U.S. Mint]] "Coin of the Month" page (geared for children) on the 1995 Special Olympics Commemorative Silver Dollar {{S-start}} {{s-ach}} {{s-bef|before= [[William Cohen]]}} {{s-ttl|title= [[Theodore Roosevelt Award (NCAA)]]|years= '''2002'''}} {{s-aft|after= [[Donna de Varona]]}} {{S-end}} {{Special Olympics}} {{Maryland Women's Hall of Fame}} {{National Women's Hall of Fame}} {{Kennedy family}} {{John F. {{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{for|the artist|Farhad Moshiri (artist)}} {{Infobox person | name = Farhad Moshiri | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Ardavan Farhad Moshiri | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1955|5|18}} | birth_place = [[Iran]] | residence = [[Monaco]] | nationality = Iranian | citizenship = British | alma_mater = [[University College London]] | occupation = Shareholder of ''[[Everton F.C.|Everton]]''{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Everton/status/703622122745241601 |title=Everton on Twitter: "BREAKING: The Club is to have a new major shareholder in Farhad Moshiri who brings the promise of new investment. More to follow. #EFC" |publisher=Twitter |date=18 August 2008 |accessdate=27 February 2016}}{{Primary source inline|date=December 2017}}
Shareholder of ''USM Holdings''
Shareholder of ''[[MegaFon]]''
Shareholder of ''[[Metalloinvest]]'' | salary = | spouse = [[Nazenin Ansari]] (ex-wife) | children = 2 | website = | signature = | footnotes = | networth = {{aligned table|[[United States dollar|US$]]1.7 billion|([[The World's Billionaires|2018 Forbes list]]){{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/farhad-moshiri/ |title=Farhad Moshiri |work=Forbes |accessdate=10 May 2018}}|US$2.3 billion|(2017 Forbes list)}} }} '''Ardavan Farhad Moshiri''' ({{lang-fa|اردوان فرهاد ﻣﺸﻴﺮى}}; born 18 May 1955) is an [[Iran]]ian businessman and investor who resides in [[Monaco]].{{cite web|url=http://washpost.bloomberg.com/Story?docId=1376-MHSZ170UQVI901-6JKCUG05DMTCTUF8DTV446I9V1 |title=Business: Washington Post Business Page, Business News |publisher=Bloomberg L.P. |accessdate=5 September 2015}} Moshiri owns and has shares in numerous steel and energy companies in the UK and Russia, as well as a 68.6% stake in [[Everton F.C.]].''[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45485034 More about Farhad Moshiri. And is it David Dein's ego vs Arsenal's interest?]''. BBC UK. Retrieved 11 September 2018. ==Early life== Moshiri was born in Iran, and his parents left just before the revolution in 1979.{{cite news|author=Andy Hunter |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/feb/28/everton-majority-shareholder-farhad-moshiri-increase-stake-bill-kenwright |title=Everton's new majority shareholder Farhad Moshiri likely to increase stake | Football |website=[[The Guardian]] |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=2 March 2016}} Moshiri has said that his father was "an [[Imperial Iranian Army|army]] doctor who trained as a pathologist and later became a senior military judge", and his mother "came from Iran's leading publishing house, ''[[Kayhan]]''."{{cite news|title=Everton takeover – Farhad Moshiri who is he?|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/everton-takeover-farhad-moshiri-who-10959138|accessdate=2 March 2016|work=Liverpool Echo|date=27 February 2016}} He was educated at [[University College London]], and trained in the UK as a [[chartered certified accountant]]. ==Career== Moshiri worked for [[Ernst & Young]], [[PKF International|PKF]] and [[Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu|Deloitte]].[http://www.metinvest.com/eng/metalloinvest/rykovodstvo/Board_of_directors/Moshiri_F/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100131150526/http://www.metinvest.com/eng/metalloinvest/rykovodstvo/Board_of_directors/Moshiri_F/ |date=31 January 2010 }} Moshiri and longstanding business partner [[Alisher Usmanov]] were co-owners of Red & White Holdings, which bought 14.65% of the shares in [[Arsenal F.C.]] from former club vice-chairman [[David Dein]] in August 2007. On 18 September 2007, Red and White Holdings increased their stake in Arsenal to 21%, and on 28 September 2007 to 23%, a week after Moshiri announced that he wanted at least a 25% holding in the football club. As of June 2012, Red and White Holdings have acquired at least 29.72%. Arsenal managing director Keith Edelman told [[BBC Radio 5 Live]], "They've said previously they are not going to make a bid for the company and they want to be long-term shareholders."{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} In February 2016 it was announced that Moshiri had sold his stake in Arsenal Football Club to Red & White Holdings partner Usmanov in a bid to raise capital required to launch a takeover at [[Everton F.C.]]{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/everton/12175747/Everton-poised-for-takeover-by-former-Arsenal-shareholder-Farhad-Moshiri.html |title=Everton poised for takeover by former Arsenal shareholder Farhad Moshiri |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=27 February 2016}} On 27 February, the club officially confirmed Moshiri's purchase of a 49.9% stake in the club, which was ratified two weeks later by the [[Premier League]]. He currently part owns Everton F.C. ==Personal life== Moshiri lives in Monaco. His former wife [[Nazenin Ansari]] is a London-based Iranian journalist, managing editor of Kayhan London, a weekly Persian-language newspaper, and series producer at Manoto, an international free-to-air Persian language TV channel.{{cite news|last=Miles |first=Tina |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/liverpool-news/who-farhad-moshiris-wife-nazenin-10971357 |title=Who is Farhad Moshiri's wife Nazenin Ansari? |newspaper=[[Liverpool Echo]] |date=27 February 2016 |accessdate=2 March 2016}} They have two children. ==References== {{Reflist|40em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Moshiri, Farhad}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of University College London]] [[Category:Arsenal F.C. directors and chairmen]] [[Category:British businesspeople]] [[Category:British expatriates in Monaco]] [[Category:English football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:English people of Iranian descent]] [[Category:Everton F.C. directors and chairmen]] [[Category:Iranian billionaires]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Iranian emigrants to the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Iranian football chairmen and investors]] [[Category:Businesspeople of Iranian descent]] {{UK-business-bio-1950s-stub|LUIS SUAREZ BID=Part owner of Arenal when club offered Liverpool FC £40m +£1.}}

{{Infobox NRHP | name = First Shearith Israel Graveyard | nrhp_type = | image = First-Shearith-Israel-Graveyard.jpg | caption = | location = 55-57 Saint James Place, [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|45|N|73|59|54|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin =Lower Manhattan#New York#USA | built = {{Start date|1682}} | added = April 17, 1980 | area = Less than {{convert|1|acre}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 80002689<ref name=nris>{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> | designated_other2_name = NYC Landmark | designated_other2_date = February 1, 1966 | designated_other2_abbr = NYCL | designated_other2_link = New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission | designated_other2_number = | designated_other2_color = #FFE978 }} '''First Shearith Israel Graveyard''' — also known as '''Chatham Square Cemetery''' — is a tiny [[List of Jewish cemeteries in New York City|Jewish graveyard]] at 55-57 St James Place in [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. It is the oldest of three Manhattan graveyards currently maintained by [[Congregation Shearith Israel]] ([[Hebrew]], "Remnant of Israel"), which is itself the oldest [[Jewish]] congregation in [[North America]].<ref name="guide2nyc">Dolkart, Andrew S. & Postal, Matthew A.; ''Guide to New York City Landmarks'', 3rd Edition; New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission; John Wiley & Sons, Inc. 2004. {{ISBN|0-471-36900-4}}; p.41.</ref><ref name=mfrench>{{cite web | title = First Shearith Israel Cemetery | publisher = Mary French | url = https://nycemetery.wordpress.com/2010/12/01/first-shearith-israel-cemetery-chatham-square-cemetery/ | date = December 1, 2010 | accessdate = 25 April 2017}}</ref> (The Congregation was formed by Spanish and Portuguese [[Sephardic Jewish]] immigrants in 1654.) Today, the cemetery is a mere fragment of its original extent. Only about a hundred headstones and above ground tombs can still be seen in what remains of the old burial ground, which rises slightly above street level. It is the only remaining 17th century structure in Manhattan.<ref name="AIA">White, Norval & Willensky, Elliot; ''[[American Institute of Architects|AIA]] Guide to New York City'', 4th Edition; New York Chapter, American Institute of Architects; Crown Publishers/Random House. 2000. {{ISBN|0-8129-3106-8}}; {{ISBN|0-8129-3107-6}}. p.80.</ref>
==History==
[[File:Cemitey Manhattan.jpg|thumb|Graveyard]] What is now called the "First Shearith Israel Graveyard," near [[Chatham Square]] in [[Lower Manhattan]], was in use from 1683 to 1833. An older cemetery called "Beth Haim," dated to 1656 — two years after the community arrived, was located around the corner of Madison and Oliver Streets.<ref>{{cite book |last= Haswell |first= Charles Haynes |date= 1896 |title= Reminiscences of an Octogenarian of the City of New York (1816 to 1860)|publisher= Harper & Brothers |page= 211}}</ref> The site for First Shearith Israel Graveyard was originally on a hill overlooking the [[East River]] in an open area at the northern periphery of the British-Dutch colonial settlement. The plot was purchased in 1682 by Joseph Bueno de Mesquita, and its first interment was for his relative, Benjamin Bueno de Mesquita, the following year. The cemetery expanded in the 1700s so that at one point it extended from Chatham Square over what is now the upper part of Oliver Street down to [[Madison Street (Manhattan)|Bancker (now Madison) Street]].<ref name=first>{{cite web | title = Chatham Square Cemetery | publisher = Shearith Israel | url = http://shearithisrael.org/content/chatham-square-cemetery | accessdate = 27 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=FSSSC>{{cite web | title = Cemeteries of Congregation Shearith Israel - The Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue | publisher = Foundation for the Study of Sephardic Studies and Culture | url = http://www.sephardicstudies.org/csi11.html | accessdate = 27 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=mfrench/><ref name=untapped>{{cite web | title = The NYC Cemetery That Moved Four Times: The Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue Cemetery | publisher = Untapped Cities | url = http://untappedcities.com/2015/06/26/the-nyc-cemetery-that-moved-four-times-the-spanish-and-portuguese-synagogue-cemetery/ | date = 26 June 2015 | accessdate = 27 December 2016}}</ref>
In a letter in 1776, a staff officer of General [[George Washington]] recommended emplacing an artillery battery "at the foot of the Jews' burying ground" to help secure [[Long Island Sound]]. American prisoners of war were buried en masse in entrenchments beyond the graveyard.<ref>{{cite book |last= Stone |first= William L. |date= 1876 |title= The Centennial History of New York City |publisher= R. D. Cooke |page= 148}}</ref> In 1823, a city ordinance prohibited burials south of [[Canal Street (Manhattan)|Canal Street]], compelling the congregation to rely on its second burial ground, consecrated in 1805 at West 11th Street in [[Greenwich Village]].<ref name=second>{{cite web | title = West 11th Street Cemetery | publisher = Shearith Israel | url = http://shearithisrael.org/content/west-11th-street-cemetery | accessdate = 27 December 2016}}</ref> (Notwithstanding this, a few more burials took place at Chatham Square up to 1833.) Much of this burden was alleviated in 1829, when Shearith Israel's third cemetery was consecrated at 21st Street just west of 6th Avenue.<ref name=mfrench /><ref name=third>{{cite web | title = Twenty-First Street Cemetery | publisher = Shearith Israel | url = http://shearithisrael.org/content/twenty-first-street-cemetery | accessdate = 27 December 2016}}</ref>
Encroaching development and erosion necessitated several instances over the years in which the congregation was forced reduce the size of the Chatham Square Cemetery and disinter bodies, which were moved to their three other graveyards. In 1851, city public health officials prohibited burial south of 86th Street and in partnership with other synagogues, the congregation purchased a large plot of land in [[Ridgewood, Queens]] as a fourth cemetery. The most notable of these instances was in 1855, when a large portion of the cemetery was seized by [[eminent domain]]. This accommodated expansion of the [[Bowery]] — including the cut-through of today's St. James Place — and some 256 graves were removed.
Today, access to the cemetery is by appointment only.
==Interees==
From 1656 until 1825, all of the practicing Jews of New York City belonged to the Shearith Israel congregation and were buried here, including 22 who fought in the Revolutionary War. Among the notable interees (which may include those whose bodies were later removed) were... * Reverend [[Gershom Mendes Seixas]] (1745–1816), the first American born Jewish spiritual leader * Dr. Walter Jonas Judah, the second Jew known to attend an American medical school (King's College, now [[Columbia University]]) and the first native-born Jew to do so; he died at age 20 of [[Yellow fever epidemic of 1793|yellow fever]]
==External links== * {{cite web | title = Chatham Square Cemetery | publisher = Shearith Israel | url = http://shearithisrael.org/content/chatham-square-cemetery | date = | accessdate = 27 December 2016}}

==Further reading== *[[David de Sola Pool|De Sola Pool, David]] (1953), ''Portraits Etched in Stone: Early Jewish Settlers, 1682-1841''; New York: [[Columbia University Press]], 543 pgs. (Sketches of interees)

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Format | image_file = Format zeitschrift.png | image_size = | image_caption = Logo of ''Format'' magazine | editor = | editor_title = | frequency = Weekly | circulation = 50,000 (2014) | category = Business magazine | company =[[Gruner + Jahr]] | publisher =[[News (publishing)|Verlagsgruppe NEWS]] | founded = 1998 | finaldate = 21 December 2015 | country =[[Austria]] | based = [[Vienna]] | language = [[German language|German]] | website = {{URL|http://www.format.at/}} | issn = | oclc = }} '''''Format''''' was a [[German language|German]] weekly finance and business [[magazine]] published in [[Austria]] and headquartered in [[Vienna]]. The magazine existed between 1998 and 21 December 2015.
==History and profile== ''Format'' was established in 1998.<ref name=pub>{{cite web|title=Format|url=http://www.publicitas.com/en/global/media-solutions/media-search/media-factsheet-detail/?PARAM1=NW5FW1#.UlV3AGRJVgs|work=Publicitas|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> The magazine had its headquarters in Vienna and was published weekly on Fridays.<ref name=blei/><ref name=w3>{{cite web|title=Austrian magazines|url=http://www.w3newspapers.com/austria/magazines/|work=w3newspapers|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> The publisher was the [[News (publishing)|Verlagsgruppe NEWS]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Science News? Overview of Science Reporting in the EU|url=http://ec.europa.eu/research/conferences/2007/bcn2007/overview_of_science_reporting_eu_en.pdf|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=22 November 2014|format=Report|year=2007}}</ref> [[Gruner + Jahr]] had a stake in the magazine.<ref name=gj>{{cite web|title=World of media|url=http://www.guj.de/en/world-of-media/format-aut/|work=G+J|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Business Press in Austria|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/iehc2006/papers2/Natmessn.pdf|work=Helsinki|accessdate=8 October 2013|author=Charlotte Natmeßnig}}</ref>
''Format'' covered topics mainly on business, politics, culture and lifestyles.<ref name=w3/> The magazine also featured the views of bankers, trade experts and financiers.<ref name=esi>{{cite web|title=Communicating Europe: Austria Manual|url=http://www.esiweb.org/pdf/enlargement_debates_manual_austria.pdf|work=European Stability Initiative|accessdate=12 October 2013|date=12 December 2007}}</ref> One of its former [[editors-in-chief]] is Peter Pelinka.<ref name=esi/>
The magazine merged with its sister publication ''[[Trend (magazine)|Trend]]'' at the end of 2015.<ref name=tas/> The last issue of ''Format'' was published on 21 December 2015.<ref name=tas>{{cite news|title=Business magazines Format and Trend will merge to form one title: Trend|url=http://www.publicitas.com/global/media-news-events/news-detail/?no_cache=1&newsid=126190&title=austria-business-magazines-format-and-trend-will-merge-to-form-one-title-trend#.V_uZs5OLT6Y|accessdate=10 October 2016|work=Publicitas|date=26 November 2015}}</ref>
==Circulation== ''Format'' had a circulation of 68,000 copies in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Media Markets: Austria Country Overview|url=http://oldtelecoms.kondrashov.ru/world/austria.html|work=Russian Telecom|accessdate=1 January 2015|date=August 2004}}</ref> Its circulation was 50,000 copies in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |author=Anne Austin et. al. |title=Western Europe Market & Media Fact |url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202008.pdf |work=ZenithOptimedia |accessdate=8 April 2015 |date=2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205131709/http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact_2008/Western%20Europe%20Market%20%26%20MediaFact%202008.pdf |archivedate=5 February 2015 |df=dmy }}</ref> The sold circulation of the weekly was 47,155 copies in 2009.<ref name=blei>{{cite web|title=Format – the Austrian Business Magazine (weekly)|url=http://www.bleispa.it/_uploads/Testate/Approfondimenti/pfdApprofondimentoT5321329app350.pdf|work=Blei|accessdate=22 February 2015}}</ref> In 2010 its circulation was 61,000 copies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Western Europe Media Facts. 2011 Edition|url=http://conan.lib.muohio.edu/ebooks/Western_Europe_Market_MediaFact/2011/Western%20Europe%20Market%20&%20MediaFact%202011.pdf|work=ZenithOptimedia|accessdate=6 March 2016}}</ref> Its circulation in 2012 was 31,021 copies.<ref name=gj/> The circulation of the magazine during the first half of 2013 increased to 39,296 copies.<ref>{{cite web|title=List of represented titles. Magazines|url=http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|work=Publicitas International AG|accessdate=29 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030071650/http://www.publicitas.com/fileadmin/uploads/common/Promotions/2013-11_Rep_List_MAGAZINES.pdf|archivedate=30 October 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The magazine sold 50,000 copies in 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Austria: dominance of the tabloids|url=http://www.eurotopics.net/en/149419|accessdate=10 October 2016|work=Euro Topics}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of magazines in Austria]]

[[File:Gulf of Maine Closure Areas.jpg|thumb|388x388px|Gulf of Maine Closed Areas]]The [[Gulf of Maine]] has been fished since the 1700s, and has been a historic fishing area since. Climate change is having significant impacts on this ecosystem; between 2004 and 2013, the Gulf of Maine has warmed faster than 99.9% of the global oceans, increasing average temperature by {{Convert|2|C-change|}}.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pershing|first=Andrew J.|last2=Alexander|first2=Michael A.|last3=Hernandez|first3=Christina M.|last4=Kerr|first4=Lisa A.|last5=Bris|first5=Arnault Le|last6=Mills|first6=Katherine E.|last7=Nye|first7=Janet A.|last8=Record|first8=Nicholas R.|last9=Scannell|first9=Hillary A.|date=2015-11-13|title=Slow adaptation in the face of rapid warming leads to collapse of the Gulf of Maine cod fishery|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/350/6262/809|journal=Science|language=en|volume=350|issue=6262|pages=809–812|doi=10.1126/science.aac9819|issn=0036-8075|pmid=26516197}}</ref> Having seen the depletion of [[groundfish]] stocks starting in the early 1990s, managers took care to create five closure areas in the Gulf of Maine.
These closed areas do not prohibit all fishing, rather they prevent the further degradation of [[Benthic zone|benthic]] habitat and groundfish species. Closed areas are different than [[Marine protected area|Marine Protected Areas]] (MPA) because they allow some forms of fishing and other activities to occur that would normally not be allowed in MPA.
== Western Gulf of Maine Closure Area ==
=== Background === The Western Gulf of Maine Closure Area (WGoMAC) was established in 1998 in response to the decreasing [[Atlantic cod|Atlantic Cod]] (''Gadus morhua'') stock.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol17/iss1/art20/|title = Ecology and Society: Implementing the Western Gulf of Maine Area Closure: The Role and Perception of Fishers' Ecological Knowledge|website = www.ecologyandsociety.org|access-date = 2016-03-24}}</ref> WGoMAC is located off the shores of Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Maine and is approximately {{Convert|3100|km2||abbr=on}}.<ref name=":0" /> It is rectangular and runs in straight lines from 42° 15' to 43° 15' North, and 69° 55' to 70° 15' West.<ref name=":1" />
It is a year long closed area that prevents groundfish fishing.<ref name=":0" /> Fishing vessels that are using exempted gear (pelagic trawls and nets) are allowed.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = https://www.greateratlantic.fisheries.noaa.gov/regs/infodocs/multsclosedareas.pdf|title = Northeast (NE) Multispecies Information Sheet Closed Area Regulations|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}}</ref> Charter and recreational vessels are allowed and may fish with a Letter of Authorization (LOA) from a Regional Administrator.<ref name=":1" />
== Cashes Ledge Closure Area ==
=== Background === Cashes Ledge Closure Area (CL) was permanently closed in 1998, in response to overfished groundfish resources.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Murawski|first=Steven A.|last2=Wigley|first2=Susan E.|last3=Fogarty|first3=Michael J.|last4=Rago|first4=Paul J.|last5=Mountain|first5=David G.|date=2005-01-01|title=Effort distribution and catch patterns adjacent to temperate MPAs|url=http://icesjms.oxfordjournals.org/content/62/6/1150|journal=ICES Journal of Marine Science: Journal du Conseil|language=en|volume=62|issue=6|pages=1150–1167|doi=10.1016/j.icesjms.2005.04.005|issn=1054-3139}}</ref> The area boundaries of the five sided polygon that is CL run from 42° 42.5' to 43° 0.7' North, and 68° 46' to 69° 26' West.<ref name=":1" />
Cashes Ledge is a shallow habitat ({{Convert|30-33|m||abbr=on}}) known for being rocky bottom habitat, located {{Convert|130|km||abbr=on}} off the Northeastern US shore.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Pinnegar|first=J.k.|last2=Polunin|first2=N.v.c.|last3=Francour|first3=P.|last4=Badalamenti|first4=F.|last5=Chemello|first5=R.|last6=Harmelin-Vivien|first6=M.-L.|last7=Hereu|first7=B.|last8=Milazzo|first8=M.|last9=Zabala|first9=M.|date=2000-06-01|title=Trophic cascades in benthic marine ecosystems: lessons for fisheries and protected-area management|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/article_S0376892900000205|journal=Environmental Conservation|volume=|issue=02|pages=179–200|doi=|issn=1469-4387}}</ref> It is a year long closed area that prevents groundfish fishing.<ref name=":1" /> Fishing vessels that are using exempted gear (pelagic trawls and nets) are allowed.<ref name=":1" /> Charter and recreational vessels are allowed and may fish with a Letter of Authorization (LOA) from a Regional Administrator.<ref name=":1" />
=== Impact on fisheries === This area serves as habitat for fish such as cod and pollock,<ref name=":2" /> and cod found in these areas have a higher mean age and gut fullness.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://icesjms.oxfordjournals.org/content/73/2/316.full|title=A comparison of cod life-history parameters inside and outside of four year-round groundfish closed areas in New England, USA|access-date=2016-03-25}}</ref> This indicates that the closed area is working, and the fish are living longer and have access to more food. With cod stock having been decreased steadily since the early 1990s, having healthier and more robust fish will positively impact the ecosystem.<ref name=":3" />
== Closed Area I ==
=== Background === Closed Area I (CA-I) was established in 1994 in an effort to protect [[Benthic zone|benthic]] habitat and groundfish species.<ref name=":3" /> The area boundaries of the four sided polygon run from 40° 45' to 41° 30' North and 68° 30' to 69° 23' West.<ref name=":1" />
It is a year long closed area that prevents groundfish fishing.<ref name=":1" /> Fishing vessels that are suing exempted gear (pelagic trawls and nets) are allowed.<ref name=":1" /> Vessels using a midwater trawl are allowed and may fish with a LOA from a Regional Administrator.<ref name=":1" /> Because of the success of the scalloping industry, [[Scallop#Wild_fisheries|scallop fishing]] is allowed, as well as vessels in the multispecies Special Access Program (SAP).<ref name=":1" />
=== Impact on fisheries === CA-I is known for high aggregations of [[haddock]], with 73% of the US catch being within {{Convert|5|km||abbr=on}} of the closed area.<ref name=":4" /> It is an area also known for [[winter flounder]] and [[yellowtail flounder]], suggesting these closed areas are aiding unsustainable populations.<ref name=":4" /> The northern edge of CA-I is fished intensely.<ref name=":4" />
== Closed Area II ==
=== Background === Closed Area II (CA-II) was established in 1994 in an effort to protect [[Benthic zone|benthic]] habitat and groundfish species.<ref name=":3" /> The area boundaries of the four sided polygon run from 41° 00' to 42° 22' North and 66° 35.8' to 67° 20' West.<ref name=":1" />
It is a year long closed area that prevents groundfish fishing.<ref name=":1" /> Fishing vessels that are suing exempted gear (pelagic trawls and nets) are allowed.<ref name=":1" /> Vessels using a midwater trawl are allowed and may fish with a LOA from a Regional Administrator.<ref name=":1" /> Because of the success of the scalloping industry, scallop fishing is allowed, as well as vessels in the groundfish Special Access Program (SAP).<ref name=":1" />
=== Impact on fisheries === This area serves as habitat for fish such as cod and pollock,<ref name=":2" /> and cod found in these areas have a higher mean age and gut fullness.<ref name=":3"/> This indicates that the closed area is working, and the fish are living longer and have access to more food. With cod stock having been decreased steadily since the early 1990s, having healthier and more robust fish will positively impact the ecosystem.<ref name=":3" /> The southern edge of CA-II is fished intensely.<ref name=":4" />
== Nantucket Lightship Closed Area ==
=== Background === Nantucket Lightship Closed Area (NLCA) was established in 1994 in an effort to protect [[Benthic zone|benthic]] habitat and groundfish species.<ref name=":3" /> It is rectangular and runs in straight lines from 40° 20' to 40° 50' North, and 69° 00' to 70° 20' West.<ref name=":1" />
It is a year long closed area that prevents groundfish fishing.<ref name=":1" /> Fishing vessels that are using exempted gear (pelagic trawls and nets) are allowed.<ref name=":1" /> Vessels using a midwater trawl are allowed and may fish with a LOA from a Regional Administrator.<ref name=":1" /> Because of the success of the scalloping industry, scallop fishing is allowed, as well as vessels using [[Atlantic surf clam|surf clam]] or [[quahog]] dredging gear.<ref name=":1" /> Charter and recreational vessels are also allowed and may fish with a LOA from a Regional Administrator.<ref name=":1" />

'''IDDEA (Interactive Discovery & Design by Evolutionary Algorithms)''' is a [[quantitative marketing research|quantitative method]] used by [[Affinnova]], a market research company. This method involves generating and presenting a number of design alternatives to persons who are participating in the design, selection, or market research exercise.
The participants (referred to as “selectors”) transmit data indicative of their preferences among or between the presented design alternatives, and that data is used to derive a new generation of design alternatives or proposals. The new designs are generated through the use of a computer program exploiting a genetic or evolutionary computational technique. The process is repeated, typically for many iterations or cycles.
This technology is very effective in brand development, product optimization and concept testing. Compared to [[conjoint analysis (in marketing)]], IDDEA can search through billions of options and quantifiably identify interaction effects for top performing concepts.
==See also== * [[Marketing]] * [[New product development]] * [[Positioning (marketing)|Product positioning]] * [[Advertising]] * [[Marketing research]] * [[Quantitative marketing research]]

'''[[Intellectual property]]''' (IP) consists of four kinds: [[patent]], [[trademark]], [[copyright]], and [[trade secret]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bramson|first=R.S.|date=1981|title=Intellectual property as collateral — patents, trade secrets, trademarks and copyrights.|url=|journal=The Business Lawyer|volume=36|pages=1567-1604|via=JSTOR}}</ref> In order to understand these areas and use them correctly, a person needs to be trained and educated. That training may be delivered through various types of resources, including webinars, college courses, webpages, and books. Intellectual property education should teach the individual what these areas are, what aspects of the law apply to them, and how to understand normal situations which might arise regarding those specific area. Because of its importance, intellectual property education should be available to people of all age groups and education levels. Because intellectual property laws are specific to each country, training on the topic is also specific to each country.
Copyright protects original expression of ideas in different forms, but not the ideas themselves. The goal of copyright law is to encourage individual and business entities to produce original work by rewarding them with exclusive rights for their benefits, which is subject to time and statutory exceptions.
As outlined in the United States Copyright Office's guide, [https://www.copyright.gov/circs/circ01.pdf Circular 1: Copyright Basics]<ref name=":0">United States Copyright Office, Library of Congress. (2017). ''Copyright Basics'' (Circular 1). Washington, D.C.: U.S. Government Printing Office.</ref>, a work is given copyright protection once it is fixed within a tangible medium, which includes "written works, musical works, dramatic works, pantomimes and choreographic works, pictorial works, graphic works, sculptural works, motion pictures and other audiovisual works, sound recordings, and architectural works." <ref name=":0" /> The copyright protection given to the work provides the owner of the work with specific rights including the right to reproduce the work, the right to create a derivative work, the right to perform the work, the right to display the work, and the right to distribute copies of the work. <ref name=":0" />
== Governing Laws of Copyright ==
=== Constitution === United States copyrights law is based in U.S. Constitution, which authorizes Congress to provide authors with certain exclusive rights in their writings for a limited period of time.<ref><nowiki>https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/10617</nowiki> U.S.C.A. § 106</ref> The "writings" is a broad term, which means any work of original expression in any form or medium, including literary, artistic, musical and etc.. "Authors" is also a broad term, which includes all creators of works.
=== Copyright Act of 1976 === Copyright law is primarily governed by federal statute and the current controlling statute is Copyright Act of 1976, as amended.[https://www.copyright.gov/title17/title17.pdf] Under the [[Supremacy Clause|Supremacy Clause of Constitution]]<ref>U.S. Const. art. 6, cl. 2.</ref>, with few exceptions, the Copyright Act of 1976 preempts state law.
=== Regulations === The US Copyright Office administers copyrights authorized by the Copyright Act, whose functions include rulemaking, regulate copyright registration, administering statutory and compulsory licenses. It also provides legal and regulatory background information as well as procedural guidance on its [https://copyright.gov/ website].
=== TEACH Act === The federal [[TEACH Act]] (Technology, Education, and Copyright Harmonization Act of 2002) was signed in November 2002, and governs the use of copyrighted materials in online learning environments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://copyright.cornell.edu/teach-act|title=New Copyright Legislation (TEACH Act) {{!}} Copyright Information Center|website=copyright.cornell.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref> The TEACH Act eases some of the rules put in place by the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://er.educause.edu/articles/2006/1/managing-intellectual-property-for-distance-learning|title=Managing Intellectual Property for Distance Learning|access-date=2018-11-29|language=en}}</ref> Many universities, including the University of Washington,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://depts.washington.edu/uwcopy/Copyright_Law/TEACH_Act/|title=UW Copyright Connection : TEACH Act : TEACH Act|website=depts.washington.edu|access-date=2018-11-29}}</ref> provide information about compliance with the TEACH Act, often related to the use of [[Learning management system|learning management systems]]
=== State Law === Though the Copyright Act preempts state law, state law covers the issues which is outside the scope of Copyright Act, such as works of authorship that have not been expressed in a tangible medium(outside of scope of "[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/102 fixed in any tangible medium of expression]"<ref>17 U.S.C. § 102(a)</ref>), right not equivalent to any of the "[https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/106 exclusive rights]"<ref>17 U.S.C. § 106</ref>, etc..
=== International Copyright Treaties === International copyright treaties between U.S. and other foreign jurisdictions is enforceable in U.S. territory under the Supremacy Clause, including: [[Berne Convention|The Berne Convention]], [[Universal Copyright Convention|The Universal Copyright Convention]], [[WIPO Copyright Treaty|The WIPO Copyright Treaty]], [[WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty|The WIPO Performances and Phonograms Treaty]], [[Geneva Phonograms Convention|The Geneva Phonograms Convention]] and [[TRIPS Agreement|TRIPS]]. While their specific terms are different, two fundamental rules govern each member under each treaty: member countries must meet certain minimum standards for copyright protection in their local law and provide reciprocal treatment to copyright owners in other member jurisdictions. The copyright law provided by each jurisdiction is based on its own national laws.
== Popular Topics ==
=== Fair Use === [[Fair use]] is one important topic in Copyright and Intellectual Property Education. Fair use law allows for limited use of copyrighted materials without seeking and/or acquiring copyright clearance from the copyright owner. There are four factors of fair use: (1) the purpose and character of the use, (2) the nature of the copyrighted work, (3) the amount or portion used of the work, and (4) the effect of the use<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/461034081|title=Copyright and cultural institutions: Guidelines for digitization for U.S. libraries, archives, and museums|last=Hirtle|first=Peter, B.|date=|publisher=Cornell University Library|others=Hudson, Emily., & Kenyon, Andrew T.|year=2009|isbn=9780935995107|location=Ithaca, N.Y.|pages=|oclc=461034081}}</ref>. Faculty, staff, and students may find a [https://copyright.columbia.edu/basics/fair-use/fair-use-checklist.html#Fair%20Use%20Checklist Fair Use Checklist] helpful when determining whether or not their use of a material would fall under fair use. Columbia University Libraries' [https://copyright.columbia.edu/index.html Copyright Advisory Services] provides their own [https://copyright.columbia.edu/basics/fair-use/fair-use-checklist.html#Fair%20Use%20Checklist Fair Use Checklist] and information about fair use law, as well as other information regarding copyright<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://copyright.columbia.edu/index.html|title=Copyright Advisory Services|last=|first=|date=|website=Columbia University Libraries|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=15 November 2018}}</ref>.
For further clarification on Fair Use and how to determine if a person's use falls under that exception, Stanford University has a [https://fairuse.stanford.edu/charts-and-tools/ Charts and Tools] section on their website. This website includes links to codes of best practices - including the Center for Media & Social Impact's [http://cmsimpact.org/code/code-best-practices-fair-use-media-literacy-education/ Code of Best Practices in Fair Use for Media Literacy Education], a [http://dirc.vraweb.org/ Digital Image Rights Computator] to help a user discover if an image they wish to use is copyrighted, and a [http://navigator.carolon.net/ Copyright Navigator] that provides basic information on how copyright law works. Each of the links on the website equips a user with enough resources to determine if their use of a copyrighted material falls under the protection of Fair Use.
The legislative intent for fair use in Section 107 in Copyright Act is stated as following: "the bill endorses the purpose and general scope of the judicial doctrine of fair use, but there is no disposition to freeze the doctrine in the statute, especially during a period of rapid technological change. Beyond a very broad statutory explanation of what fair use is and some of the criteria applicable to it, the courts must be free to adapt the doctrine to particular situations on a case-by-case basis. Section 107 is intended to restate the present judicial doctrine of fair use, not to change, narrow, or enlarge it in any way."<ref><nowiki>https://law.resource.org/pub/us/works/aba/ibr/H.Rep.94-1476.pdf</nowiki> H.R. REP. 94-1476, 66, 1976 U.S.C.C.A.N. 5659, 5680</ref> It means courts have broad discretion to decide fair use application. U.S. Copyright Office creates a [https://www.copyright.gov/fair-use/fair-index.html Fair Use Index] which summarizes the newest case law development in fair use.
=== Public Domain === [[Public Domain]] is another important concept in Copyright and Intellectual Property Education. If a work is in public domain - i.e., if its copyright has expired, been lost, or was never given - that work may be used by anyone. In order to help determine if a work is in Public Domain, Cornell University provides a [https://copyright.cornell.edu/publicdomain Public Domain Flow Chart] to help users identify if a work is protected by copyright law. Stanford University Libraries' guide, [https://fairuse.stanford.edu/overview/public-domain/welcome/ Welcome to the Public Domain], also provides in-depth information that can help users identify how a work enters the public domain based on the date it was published. For example, within the United States, all works that were created prior to 1923 are currently within the public domain.<ref>Stanford University Libraries (2018). Copyright & Fair Use: Welcome to the Public Domain. ''Stanford University''. Retrieved from <nowiki>https://fairuse.stanford.edu/overview/public-domain/welcome/</nowiki></ref> In order to further understand copyright and public domain, the [https://soundcloud.com/user-864134809 Copy This Podcast] provides listeners with a brief history of Copyright Law and Public Domain. Each podcast is approximately twelve minutes long and covers topics such as "[https://soundcloud.com/user-864134809/pop-culture-and-the-public-domain Pop Culture and the Public Domain]," "[https://soundcloud.com/user-864134809/you-use-it-more-than-you-realize Fair Use: You Use It More Than You Realize]," and "[https://soundcloud.com/user-864134809/notice-and-takedown-leave-it-be Notice and Takedown: Leave it Be]." Each of these podcasts features experts and scholars of copyright law and can provide users with information about how to navigate the world of copyright.
=== Orphan Works === [[Orphan work|Orphan works]], or works where the creator or rightsholder is unable to be determined, are an important current topic in copyright law. There is currently no legislation in the United States place to fully address this issue, though progress has been made specifically for music with the [[Music Modernization Act]] in 2018.
After the [[Copyright Act of 1976]], copyright holders were no longer required to register copyrighted works, which benefited copyright holders by simplifying the process to obtain and maintain copyright protection, but in turn complicated the process for potential users of copyrighted material to determine ownership over certain works as the central register for copyrighted materials was no longer deemed necessary. This made any usage of copyrighted materials outside of fair use a violation of copyright, but did not take into account the drastic changes of access and dissemination that would soon occur due to digitization and the internet.
In 2006 the U.S. Copyright Office held a study and released a report on orphan works<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyright.gov/orphan/orphan-report.pdf|title=Report on Orphan Works|last=A Report of the Register of Copyrights|first=|date=January 2006|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>. The main conclusion was that new legislation was needed to address this issue, and that clearly delineated steps need to be identified for potential users of such works, as well as protocols set in place for when an author comes forward.
Another report, ‘Orphan Works and Mass Digitization<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyright.gov/orphan/reports/orphan-works2015.pdf|title=Orphan Works and Mass Digitization|last=A Report of the Register of Copyrights|first=|date=June 2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>’ was completed in 2012 with particular focus on how how efforts to preserve copyrighted material needed to be balanced with reasonable access to the work. This report laid out the prospective changes needed to alter the outdated legislation and better serve current informational needs.
It is also important to note that in 2013, the UK passed a copyright act<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/guidance/copyright-orphan-works|title=Guidance: Copyright: orphan works|last=Intellectual Property Office|first=|date=May 2015|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> that permitted usage of orphan works as long as a diligent effort was made and certain conditions were met, such as filing a ‘notice of use’ for the work.

'''James Walker Michaels'''<ref name=Morgenson>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/07/business/media/07gret.html|title=A Taskmaster Who Changed Business News|last=Morgenson|first=Gretchen|work=The New York Times|date=October 7, 2007|accessdate=August 26, 2018}}</ref> (June 17, 1921 – October 2, 2007) was an [[Americans|American]] [[journalist]] and magazine [[Editing|editor]]. Michaels served as the longtime editor of ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine from 1961 until his retirement in 1999.<ref name=lat>{{cite news |title= James W. Michaels, 86; former editor of Forbes|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-me-michaels5oct05,1,693358.story?coll=la-headlines-business|work= [[Bloomberg News]] |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=2007-10-05 |accessdate=2007-10-14}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
==Early life== James Michaels was born in [[Buffalo, New York]], on June 17, 1921.<ref name=afs/> He attended the [[Culver Military Academy]] in Indiana and graduated from [[Harvard University]] with a bachelor's degree in [[economics]] in 1942. Michaels joined the [[U.S. military]] during [[World War II]]. He applied to the [[American Field Service]] in April 1943 and was sent to [[Mumbai|Bombay]] India to drive an [[ambulance]] for the [[British Army]] as part of AFS India Burma Unit 1. James was the nephew of the comedy writer [[Al Boasberg]].
==Career== James Michaels stayed with the military until September 1944 when he was released to the Office of War Information. After the war, Mr. Michaels remained in India and worked for the [[United Press]] wire service's New Delhi office, giving Mr. Michaels the biggest story of his life; in 1948 he broke the story of the assassination of [[Mahatma Gandhi]]. Mr. Michaels spent over four decades with ''Forbes'' magazine, after joining as a reporter in 1954 and rising to [[managing editor]] in 1957 where he served until 1961 when he became editor.
Mr. Michaels retired from ''Forbes'' magazine in 1999 and was succeeded as editor by [[William Baldwin (editor)|William Baldwin]].<ref name=lat/> He left the magazine to help expand the [[Forbes|Forbes Inc]] [[parent company]] into new [[mediums]] including [[television]], [[books]] and [[new media]]. During his time as with Forbes, the magazine's circulation grew from 130,000 to 785,000, demonstrating how much readers enjoyed the magazine.<ref name = nytimes/>
==Editorial Style==
According to [[Allan Sloan]] of ''Fortune'' magazine, James Michaels, "was an absolutely brilliant editor who transformed business magazine journalism."<ref name=sloan>{{cite news|author=Allan Sloan |title=A farewell to a brilliant business editor |url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/10/03/magazines/fortune/sloan_michaelsobit.fortune/?postversion=2007100318 |work=Fortune.com |date=2007-10-04 |accessdate=2009-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316042641/http://money.cnn.com/2007/10/03/magazines/fortune/sloan_michaelsobit.fortune/?postversion=2007100318 |archivedate=2012-03-16 |df= }}</ref> [[Steve Forbes]] described James Michaels as a tough editor who wanted articles short, dramatic, and opinionated.<ref name = forbes/> According to the New York Times, when Michaels took over as editor, "American journalism remained a polite, dry affair, and corporate spin was reported without much skepticism. Ahead of his time, he made Forbes opinionated, interpretive and often indecorous, a magazine staunchly pro-business (and, its critics said, pro-wealthy) but did not hesitate to skewer companies and executives it saw as failures."<ref name = nytimes>{{cite news | author = RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA | title = James Michaels, Longtime Forbes Editor, Dies at 86 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/04/business/04michaels.html | work = The New York Times | date = 2007-10-04 | accessdate = 2009-05-31 }}</ref> According to Forbes, "he despised 'bad actors' who were cheating investors, customers, employees."
According to the New York Times many of his former writers and editors remember Mr. Michaels as much for his brutal assessments of their work as for his incisive teaching. While always a gentlemen and available to talk, he could not stand verbose writing and would ruthlessly cut words and forced writers to state their view. A staunch contrarian, he did not let public opinion dictate the magazines views.
Michaels focused on the needs of his readers, rather than pleasing corporate executives or the mainstream media. [[Allan Sloan]] wrote, "Unlike many of his competitors, Michaels didn't particularly lionize corporate chieftains. His focus was on representing small investors' interests."<ref name = sloan/> Mr. Michaels wrote, "MY THESIS is this: If newspapers hope to survive they would do well to be less concerned with a liberal social agenda and more with the lives, hopes, and fears of their potential readers."<ref name = national>{{cite news | author = James W. Michaels | title = One size fits none - development of politically correct slant in newspaper reporting | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1282/is_n12_v45/ai_13952926/?tag=content;co11 | work = National Review | date = 1993-06-21 | accessdate = 2009-06-03 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Michaels was a hater of [[weasel words]]. William Baldwin (current Forbes editor) wrote "Jim had a novel idea. Why not speak to the reader as if you were speaking to a friend on a street corner? Brevity helps. Judgments help. If the chairman of the company is a nincompoop, say so -- if there's evidence to prove it."<ref>{{cite news | author = William Baldwin | title = James W. Michaels, feather ruffler | url = https://www.forbes.com/forbes/1999/0111/6301116a.html | work = Forbes.com | date = 1999-01-11 | accessdate = 2009-07-10 }}</ref>
As editor, Michaels edited 1,000 issues and he worked on almost every story. He wanted articles to be shorter, more direct, and with a clear conclusion to ensure they were fit for readers. He also wanted stories in Forbes to be original. If a story had been covered in another publication, he didn't want it in the magazine. To quote him, "Our readers look to us for groundbreaking, helpful stuff. Who needs us if we're doing what everyone else is doing?"
==Contributions== Mr. Michaels' writing on Gandhi's death is included in the anthology "A Treasury of Great Reporting".<ref name=afs>{{cite web|url=http://www.afs.org/afs_or/news/index/5488 |title=James W. Michaels (1921-2007) |date=2007-11-29 |accessdate=2009-05-31 |work=AFS News |publisher=AFS Intercultural Programs |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090721140513/http://www.afs.org/afs_or/news/index/5488 |archivedate=2009-07-21 |df= }}</ref> Michaels' dispatches from India are still taught in [[journalism]] [[anthologies]] of model [[Journalism|reporting]] on [[time limit|deadline]].<ref name=lat/>
Steve Forbes credits Mr. Michaels with Forbes success. Mr. Forbes wrote, "When Jim joined FORBES in 1954, this magazine was, to put it charitably, second-tier. Moreover, business journalism itself was a backwater, a place where publications dumped their drunks and burned-out sportswriters. Today business, finance and economics are front-page stuff." "Jim made FORBES not only the most influential magazine in the business field but also one of the world's premier publications. Indeed, with no exaggeration, Jim Michaels was the foremost editor of our era. He virtually created modern business journalism."<ref name = forbes/>
In the 1950s Mr. Michaels foresaw the growth of the then nascent mutual fund industry. Michaels was integral in the development of Forbes' grading system of the long-term performance of funds.<ref name = forbes>{{cite news | authorlink = Steve_Forbes | author = Steve Forbes | title = James W. Michaels | url = https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2007/1029/023_print.html | work = Forbes.com | date = 2007-10-29 | accessdate = 2009-05-31}}</ref> He helped create the [[Forbes 400]] ranking of America's richest people, first published in 1982.
==Mentorship and Influence== Mr. Michaels has been cited as mentoring and influencing a long and influential group of writers, journalists, and editors including (but not necessarily limited to): [[Norman Pearlstine]], [[Allan Sloan]], [[Richard Behar]], [[David Churbuck]], [[Gretchen Morgenson]], [[Kenneth Fisher]], [[Peter Brimelow]], [[William M Reddig Jr]] and [[Ed Finn]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.churbuck.com/wordpress/?p=1383 | title = James W. Michaels | accessdate = 2009-06-01 | author = David Churbuck | date = 2007-10-03}}</ref>
==Awards== Michaels was honored with many awards, including the [[Gerald Loeb Award|Loeb Award]] (1972), Editor of the Year by Ad Week (1983), and Loeb Lifetime Achievement Award (1994). The TJFR Group honored Michaels by naming him one of the Top Ten Business News Luminaries of the Century.<ref name = afs/>
==Death== James Michaels died at age 86 of [[pneumonia]] on October 2, 2007 in [[Manhattan]].<ref name=lat/> Michaels was a resident of Manhattan and [[Rhinebeck, New York]], at the time of his death. Michaels was survived by his wife, Jean Briggs, whom he married June 29, 1985. Jean Briggs spent time as a senior editor and manager of the reporter/resesarcher department at Forbes.<ref>{{cite news | title = James W. Michaels Weds Jean Briggs in Rhinebeck | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9505E2DA1E39F933A05755C0A963948260 | work = The New York Times | date = 1985-06-30 | accessdate = 2009-05-31}}</ref> He was also survived by his brother (Albert), sister (Harriet), three children from a previous marriage, and six granddaughters.<ref name = nytimes/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
